text: so you have all of these different bits, and they're organized on a dram chip actually in this 2d manner
now down here at the bottom of the chip, there's two important structural pieces

first of all you have your wires, your data pins, that actually connect this chip to the rest of the computer, so there's eight data pins here, which means this dram chip at any one clock, can only send eight bits of information, there's a 1 or a 0 on each of these wires
and in order to access the dram chip the dram chip doesn't actually send data
it actually has a buffer here which is like a digital buffer that stores the values, the bits in one row of the dram chip so this is called the row buffer, so this stores one row
and so when you access data from a dram chip you're actually only accessing data for
a bite sized chunk of information stored in this row buffer
